questions.text: A 25-year-old male sustains a stab injury to the axilla. He presents with weakness in elbow flexion and forearm supination. The diagram below shows the brachial plexus with injured nerve marked X. Identify the nerve.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked structure is the musculocutaneous nerve, which arises from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus (C5-C7) and supplies coracobrachialis, biceps brachii, and brachialis, thereby enabling elbow flexion and forearm supination.

Musculocutaneous Nerve

  • Origin
    • Arises from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus (C5, C6, C7).
    • Emerges opposite the lower border of pectoralis minor.
  • Course
    • Pierces coracobrachialis (a variable distance below coracoid tip).
    • Descends between biceps brachii (anterior) and brachialis (posterior).
    • At lower arm, continues as the lateral cutaneous nerve of forearm.
  • Branches and Supply
    • First branch: to coracobrachialis (within 2 cm of coracoid).
    • Biceps brachii: consistently supplied; nerve accompanied by a vascular pedicle.
    • Brachialis: usually two branches; lower branch also supplies anterior elbow joint.
    • Small branch to humerus: enters shaft with nutrient artery.
  • Cutaneous continuation
    • Becomes lateral cutaneous nerve of forearm, supplying lateral forearm skin.

Explanation of other options:

Radial nerve (Option A): Injury leads to loss of wrist and finger extension, resulting in wrist drop, not weakness of elbow flexion or supination.

Median nerve (Option C): Responsible for wrist/finger flexion and thumb opposition; it does not supply biceps or supinators.

Ulnar nerve (Option D): Supplies intrinsic hand muscles and flexor carpi ulnaris; it does not contribute to elbow flexion or supination.

Key Takeaway:

  • Weakness of elbow flexion and supination following axillary injury is specific for musculocutaneous nerve damage.

questions.text: The image below shows a pressure-volume loop of the cardiac cycle with a marked point (X). What phase of the cardiac cycle does this point represent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked point represents ventricular ejection, where ventricular pressure exceeds aortic/pulmonary pressure and semilunar valves open, allowing blood outflow.

Ventricular Systole & Pressure-Volume Loop

  • End-diastolic volume (EDV): ~130 mL
  • Isovolumetric contraction:
    • AV valves close → ventricular pressure rises sharply.
    • No change in volume (≈130 mL).
    • Duration ≈ 0.05 s.
    • LV pressure rises to >80 mmHg (aortic opening pressure).
    • RV pressure rises to >10 mmHg (pulmonary opening pressure).
  • Ejection phase:
    • Begins when aortic & pulmonary valves open.
    • Volume decreases rapidly at first (rapid ejection), then slowly (reduced ejection).
    • LV peak pressure ≈ 120 mmHg.
    • RV peak pressure ≈ 25 mmHg.
    • Stroke volume ≈ 70-90 mL.
  • End-systolic volume (ESV): ≈ 50 mL.
  • Ejection fraction (EF): ≈ 65%.

Key Takeaway:

  • Ventricular ejection begins when ventricular pressure exceeds arterial pressure, causing semilunar valves to open and stroke volume to be ejected.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with hepatosplenomegaly, bone pain, and easy bruising. A bone marrow biopsy slide is provided, showing characteristic cells. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Deficiency of glucocerebrosidase leads to accumulation of glucocerebroside in macrophages, causing hepatosplenomegaly, bone pain, and the characteristic Gaucher cells.

Gaucher Disease

  • Autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the GBA1 gene.
  • Leads to deficiency of glucocerebrosidase, causing toxic accumulation of glucocerebroside lipids in liver, spleen, and bone marrow.
  • Histopathology:
    • Gaucher cells (lipid-laden macrophages) with characteristic wrinkled-paper cytoplasm.
    • Seen in bone marrow and liver sinusoids.
  • Clinical Features
    • Painless hepatomegaly
    • Splenomegaly
    • Hypersplenism with pancytopenia
    • Severe joint pain, especially in hips and knees
    • Impaired olfaction and cognition
    • Severe convulsions and hypertonia
    • Intellectual disability and apnea
    • Myoclonus and seizures
    • Dementia and ocular muscle apraxia
    • Parkinsonism
    • Osteoporosis
    • Yellowish-brown skin pigmentation

Explanation of other options:

Sphingomyelinase (Option B): Deficient in Niemann-Pick disease, which presents with hepatosplenomegaly and foam cells, but not wrinkled-paper macrophages.

Hexosaminidase A (Option C): Deficient in Tay-Sachs disease, primarily causes neurodegeneration without hepatosplenomegaly or bone marrow involvement.

Iduronate-2-sulfatase (Option D): Deficient in Hunter syndrome, causing coarse facial features and skeletal abnormalities, not characteristic Gaucher cells in marrow.

Key Takeaway:

  • Gaucher disease presents with hepatosplenomegaly, bone pain, pancytopenia, and wrinkled-paper macrophages due to glucocerebrosidase deficiency.

Reference:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448080/

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with generalized lymphadenopathy undergoes a lymph node biopsy. The histopathology image is taken and is shown below. Immunohistochemistry reveals positivity for CD19 and CD20. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The biopsy shows diffuse sheets of large atypical B-cells positive for CD19 and CD20, consistent with Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.

Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL)

  • Most common NHL
  • Median age: ~60 years (older adults).
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Heterogeneous group of lymphomas.
    • Genetic abnormalities:
      • BCL6 translocations (~30%) → overexpression, blocks differentiation, promotes proliferation.
      • BCL2 translocation t(14;18) (10-20%) → overexpression of anti-apoptotic BCL2, often transformed from follicular lymphoma.
      • Histone acetyltransferase mutations → altered gene expression.
      • MYC translocations (~5%) → associated with aggressive course.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Rapidly enlarging symptomatic mass (nodal or extranodal: GIT, skin, bone, brain).
    • Liver, spleen, marrow involvement usually occur late.
    • Aggressive, rapidly fatal if untreated.
    • With intensive chemotherapy ± anti-CD20 (rituximab):
      • CR in 60-80%.
      • Cure in 40-50%.
      • Limited disease → better prognosis.
  • Morphology:
    • Large cells (4-5× size of small lymphocytes).
    • Diffuse growth pattern obliterating architecture.
    • Nuclei: vesicular, variable shape, 2-3 nucleoli.
    • Cytoplasm: moderate, pale or basophilic.
  • Immunophenotype:
    • Mature B-cell markers: CD19, CD20.
    • Variable: CD10, BCL6.
    • Usually surface Ig positive.

Explanation of other options:

Hodgkin lymphoma (Option B): Shows Reed-Sternberg cells, not diffuse sheets of large B-cells.

Reactive lymphoid hyperplasia (Option C): Preserves nodal architecture with mixed cell populations, not effacement by atypical cells.

Follicular lymphoma (Option D): Shows nodular/follicular growth pattern with BCL2 positivity, not diffuse sheets of large cells.

Key Takeaway:

  • Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma is the most common NHL, presenting with diffuse sheets of large atypical B-cells expressing CD19 and CD20.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of atrial fibrillation on long-term antiarrhythmic therapy presents with progressive dyspnea and cough. Chest CT and chest X-ray images are shown below. Which drug is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Amiodarone toxicity leads to pulmonary fibrosis due to chronic tissue accumulation, especially with long-term therapy in atrial fibrillation.

Amiodarone

  • Class III antiarrhythmic drug (K+ channel blocker).
  • Highly effective at suppressing dysrhythmias.
  • Pharmacokinetics:
    • Extensively bound in tissues.
    • Very long elimination half-life (10-100 days).
    • Accumulates in the body with repeated dosing.
    • Loading dose required:
      • Given IV via a central vein for life-threatening dysrhythmias.
      • Peripheral administration → causes phlebitis.
  • Adverse Effects:
    • Dermatologic:
      • Photosensitive rashes.
      • Slate-grey/ bluish skin discolouration.
    • Endocrine:
      • Thyroid abnormalities (hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism, due to iodine content).
    • Respiratory:
      • Pulmonary fibrosis (late onset, may be irreversible).
    • Ocular:
      • Corneal deposits.
    • Neurological & GI:
      • Neurological disturbances.
      • Gastrointestinal issues, including hepatitis.

Explanation of other options:

Sotalol (Option B): Class III antiarrhythmic but does not cause pulmonary fibrosis; main risk is torsades de pointes.

Diltiazem (Option C): Calcium channel blocker; may cause bradycardia or hypotension, but no pulmonary toxicity.

Digoxin (Option D): Inhibits Na+/K+ ATPase; adverse effects include arrhythmias, GI upset, and visual disturbances, not pulmonary fibrosis.

Key Takeaway:

  • Long-term amiodarone therapy can cause pulmonary fibrosis, which is typically late in onset and may be irreversible.

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive patient presents with meningitis. A CSF India ink preparation is performed, and the microscopy image is shown below. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The India ink stain of CSF in an HIV patient shows encapsulated yeast, diagnostic of Cryptococcus neoformans meningitis.

Cryptococcus neoformans

  • Basidiomycetous yeast with a large polysaccharide capsule.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Transmission: Inhalation of desiccated yeast cells or basidiospores.
    • Primary site: Lungs (may be asymptomatic or mild respiratory illness).
    • Dissemination: Especially in immunocompromised patients → CNS (neurotropic).
    • Other sites: skin, eye, bone, adrenals, prostate.
    • Virulence factors:
      • Polysaccharide capsule (antiphagocytic).
      • Laccase enzyme → melanin formation, protection from oxidative stress.
      • Ability to grow at 37°C.
    • Inflammation: minimal or granulomatous.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Major manifestation: chronic meningitis.
      • Symptoms: headache, neck stiffness, disorientation.
      • Mimics brain tumor, abscess, degenerative CNS disease, TB/fungal meningitis.
    • CSF findings: ↑ pressure, ↑ protein, ↑ cells, normal/↓ glucose.
    • Other lesions: lungs, skin, eye, bone, prostate.
    • In AIDS: 5-8% develop cryptococcal meningitis.
    • Untreated disease → ultimately fatal.
    • Not transmitted person to person.
  • Laboratory Diagnosis:
    • Specimens: CSF, blood, tissue, sputum, urine.
    • Microscopy:
      • India ink stain → capsule visualization (negative staining).
    • Culture:
      • Whitish mucoid colonies (2-3 days).
      • Growth at 37°C.
      • Urease positive.
      • On diphenolic substrates → brown pigmented colonies (melanin via laccase).
    • Serology:
      • Detect capsular antigen (GXM) in CSF/serum/urine.
      • Latex agglutination test (positive in ~90% of meningitis).
      • Lateral flow assay (LFA): rapid, point-of-care, especially in sub-Saharan Africa.

Explanation of other options:

Candida albicans (Option B): Causes thrush, esophagitis, or catheter-related infections, not encapsulated meningitis seen with India ink.

Aspergillus fumigatus (Option C): Causes invasive pulmonary aspergillosis and angioinvasive disease, not meningitis with encapsulated yeast.

Histoplasma capsulatum (Option D): Intracellular yeast in macrophages; meningitis possible but does not show a polysaccharide capsule on India ink.

Key Takeaway:

  • In HIV patients, encapsulated yeast seen on India ink stain of CSF is characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans meningitis.

questions.text: A body recovered from a waterlogged environment is shown in the image below. What postmortem change is observed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The body shows adipocere (saponification), a waxy, whitish postmortem change of fat that occurs in waterlogged or moist conditions.

Adipocere (Saponification)

  • Modification of putrefaction.
  • Formation of soft, whitish, crumbly, waxy, greasy material in fatty tissues of a dead body.
  • Common in bodies immersed in water or damp, warm environment.
  • Mechanism:
    • Gradual hydrolysis + hydrogenation of fats (e.g., olein → higher fatty acids).
    • Fatty acids combine with Ca2+ & NH4+ ions → insoluble soaps (acidic → inhibit bacteria).
    • Final products: palmitic, oleic, stearic, hydroxystearic acids + glycerol.
    • Matrix: residual fibres, nerves, muscles.
    • Crystals with radial markings
    • Fatty acids in fat:
      • At death: ~0.5%
      • After 1 month: ~20%
      • After 3 months: >70%
    • Enzymes:
      • Intrinsic lipases start process.
      • Continued by Clostridia group (esp. Cl. perfringens) producing lecithinase → hydrolysis/hydrogenation.
    • Water essential for process.
  • Factors Influencing Formation:
    • Water helps glycerin removal & supports hydrolysis.
    • Heat → accelerates, Cold → delays.
    • Favoured by: warm, moist, anaerobic environment.
    • Common in: females, obese, newborns, well-nourished adults, submerged/buried bodies.
    • Watertight coffins can preserve adipocere for years, even without external water.
  • Distribution:
    • First in subcutaneous tissue.
    • Common sites: face, buttocks, breasts, abdomen.
    • Can involve limbs, chest wall, entire body.
  • Medicolegal Importance
    • Preserves facial features → aids identification.
    • Injuries preserved → helps determine cause of death.
    • Helps estimate time since death (though not very reliable).

Explanation of other options:

Mummification (Option B): Occurs in dry, arid environments with dehydration of tissues; does not produce waxy, soap-like deposits as seen in waterlogged bodies.

Putrefaction (Option C): General decomposition with bloating, gas, and foul odor; lacks the waxy, preserved fat characteristic of adipocere.

Rigor mortis (Option D): Temporary stiffening of muscles shortly after death; does not affect fat tissues or produce adipocere formation.

Key Takeaway:

  • Adipocere formation preserves body features and injuries, aiding identification and forensic analysis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant female presents with progressive, painless hearing loss. The image below shows an audiogram. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The audiogram shows a conductive hearing loss with a 2000 Hz Carhart's notch, indicative of otosclerosis.

Otosclerosis (Otospongiosis)

  • Primary disease of bony labyrinth.
  • Spongy bone replaces normal dense enchondral bone of otic capsule.
  • Commonest site: stapes region → stapes fixation → conductive hearing loss.

Aetiology

  • Heredity:
    • ~50% positive family history.
    • Autosomal dominant.
  • Sex:
    • Females > males (2:1).
    • In India, more common in males.
  • Age:
    • Onset usually 20-30 years.
    • Rare before 10 or after 40 years.
  • Other factors:
    • Pregnancy, menopause, trauma, surgery may worsen hearing loss.
    • Associated with osteogenesis imperfecta

Symptoms

  1. Hearing loss: Progressive, painless, usually in 20s, insidious, bilateral, conductive type.
  2. Paracusis Willisii: Hears better in noisy surroundings.
  3. Tinnitus: Common in cochlear otosclerosis or active lesions.
  4. Vertigo: Uncommon.
  5. Speech: Monotonous, low-modulated, soft speech.

Signs

  1. Tympanic membrane usually normal & mobile.
    • May show Schwartze sign (reddish hue on promontory, indicates active focus with ↑ vascularity).
  2. Tuning fork tests:
    • Rinne: negative (BC > AC)
    • Weber: lateralized to ear with greater conductive loss.
    • Absolute BC: normal (but decreased in cochlear otosclerosis).
  3. Pure tone audiometry (PTA):
    • Air conduction loss, worse at low frequencies.
    • Bone conduction normal.
    • Carhart's notch at 2000 Hz.
    • Carhart's notch disappears after successful stapedectomy.
  4. Speech audiometry:
    • Normal discrimination score (except in cochlear otosclerosis).

Explanation of other options:

Meniere's disease (Option B): Typically causes sensorineural hearing loss, fluctuating with vertigo and tinnitus, not a fixed conductive loss.

Acoustic neuroma (Option C): Causes unilateral, progressive sensorineural hearing loss with possible vestibular symptoms; audiogram shows high-frequency SNHL, not Carhart's notch.

Presbycusis (Option D): Age-related bilateral, symmetrical sensorineural hearing loss, predominantly at high frequencies, not low-frequency conductive loss seen in otosclerosis.

Key Takeaway:

  • Otosclerosis causes progressive, conductive hearing loss, often showing Carhart's notch at 2000 Hz on audiogram.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with eye pain, tearing, and photophobia. Corneal staining is performed, and the image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The branching dendritic corneal ulcer seen on staining is pathognomonic for herpes simplex keratitis.

Herpes Simplex Keratitis

  • Caused mainly by HSV-1 (herpes simplex virus type 1).
  • Usually acquired early in life (close contact e.g., kissing).
  • Often asymptomatic or may present with:
    • Fever
    • Vesicular lid lesions
    • Follicular conjunctivitis
    • Preauricular lymphadenopathy
  • May cause conjunctivitis ± punctate keratitis.
  • Followed by resolution & latency of virus in trigeminal ganglion.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Epithelial keratitis:
      • Pathognomonic lesion = dendritic ulcer (linear, branching epithelial ulcer).
      • May heal without scar or progress to stromal keratitis.
    • Stromal keratitis:
      • Inflammatory infiltration + corneal oedema.
      • Leads to loss of transparency & permanent scarring.
      • Represents immunogenic response to viral antigen.
    • Severe corneal scarring → may need corneal graft to restore vision.
    • Complications: may be associated with uveitis & glaucoma.
    • Disciform keratitis:
      • Immunogenic stromal reaction to herpes antigen.
      • Presents as disc/ring-shaped stromal oedema & clouding (no ulceration).
      • Often associated with iritis.

Explanation of other options:

Bacterial keratitis (Option B): Usually presents with purulent discharge, corneal infiltrates, and rapidly progressive pain; characteristic epithelial staining is not typical.

Acanthamoeba keratitis (Option C): Often occurs in contact lens users with severe pain disproportionate to clinical signs; early lesions appear as ring-shaped stromal infiltrates, not simple epithelial staining.

Fungal keratitis (Option D): Usually shows feathery-edged stromal infiltrates, satellite lesions, and slower progression; epithelial dendritic-like staining is not seen.

Key Takeaway:

  • The pathognomonic lesion of herpes simplex keratitis is a dendritic ulcer on the cornea.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with hypopigmented patches on the back. The image below shows the skin lesion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The hypopigmented, mildly scaly patches on the trunk in a young adult are characteristic of tinea versicolor.

Tinea Versicolor:

  • Tinea versicolor (pityriasis versicolor) is a common, benign, superficial fungal skin infection.
  • Causative Organism: Caused by Malassezia, a dimorphic lipophilic fungus (formerly Pityrosporum).
  • Characteristic Lesions: Multiple, well-demarcated, oval, finely scaling patches or plaques.
  • Color Variations:
    • Hypopigmented, hyperpigmented, or erythematous.
    • Hyperpigmented lesions: light brown in fair skin; dark brown to grayish-black in dark skin.
    • Lesions can vary in hue on the same person.
  • Distribution: Lesions can become confluent and widespread.
  • Diagnostic Sign: "Evoked scale sign" - overlying scale becomes visible when the affected skin is stretched or scraped.

Explanation of other options:

Vitiligo (Option B): Complete depigmentation, usually well-defined, no scaling.

Pityriasis alba (Option C): Mild, ill-defined hypopigmented patches, minimal or absent scaling, mostly in children.

Post-inflammatory hypopigmentation (Option D): Occurs after prior skin inflammation, usually localized, not multiple widespread patches.

Key Takeaway:

  • Tinea versicolor presents as multiple, well-demarcated, finely scaling hypopigmented or hyperpigmented patches.

Reference:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482500/

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with seizures and headache. The image below shows a brain MRI. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The MRI shows a dural-based, homogeneously enhancing mass with a dural tail, which is characteristic of meningioma.

Meningioma

  • Dural-based intradural tumours.
  • 95% are benign (WHO grade I).
  • Second most common intraspinal tumours.
  • Peak age: 50-60 years.
  • Rare in children except with Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF-2).
  • Female preponderance.
  • Location & Distribution:
    • Thoracic region: ~80% of cases.
    • Cervical region: ~40% in men.
    • Position:
      • Thoracic → mostly posterolateral.
      • Cervical → mostly anterior.
    • Usually solitary.
    • Multiple meningiomas (2%) → commonly associated with NF-2.
    • Slow-growing → may cause significant cord compression with minor symptoms.
  • Imaging Findings:
    • CT Scan:
      • Isoattenuating → hyperattenuating.
      • Hyperattenuation due to high cellularity ± calcification.
      • Hyperostosis is possible (less common than intracranial meningiomas).
    • MRI:
      • T1: Iso- to hypointense.
      • T2: Slightly hyperintense.
      • Post-gadolinium: Strong, homogeneous enhancement (except calcified areas).
      • Some tumours are heavily calcified → dark on all sequences with little contrast uptake.
      • Dural tail sign: classical but less common in spinal meningiomas than in intracranial.

Explanation of other options:

Subdural hematoma (Option B): Appears as a crescent-shaped extra-axial collection, not a solid enhancing mass.

Glioblastoma (Option C): Intra-axial tumour with heterogeneous enhancement, necrosis, and irregular margins, unlike well-circumscribed meningioma.

Cerebral abscess (Option D): Shows ring enhancement with central restricted diffusion, not solid homogeneous enhancement with dural attachment.

Key Takeaway:

  • A dural-based, well-circumscribed, strongly enhancing mass with a dural tail on MRI is most characteristic of meningioma.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with blurred vision and limb weakness. The image below shows a brain MRI. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The MRI shows periventricular demyelinating plaques ("Dawson's fingers"), which are pathognomonic for multiple sclerosis.

Multiple Sclerosis (MS)

  • Autoimmune disease of the CNS.
  • Characterised by:
    • Chronic inflammation
    • Demyelination
    • Gliosis (plaques/scarring)
    • Neuronal loss
  • Course: relapsing or progressive.
  • Plaques: disseminated in time and space (different times, different CNS locations).
  • Clinical Manifestations:
    • Onset: usually 20-40 yrs (slightly later in men).
    • Sex ratio: women are affected 3× more than men.
  • Symptoms & Signs:
    • Sensory:
      • Paresthesias: tingling, pins/needles, burning.
      • Hypesthesia: numbness, "dead feeling".
      • Unpleasant sensations: swollen, wet, raw, tightly wrapped feelings.
    • Optic neuritis (ON)
    • Motor/Weakness:
      • UMN type: spasticity, hyperreflexia, extensor plantar response.
      • Exercise-induced weakness is characteristic.
    • Cranial nerves:
      • Facial weakness (pons lesion) may mimic Bell's palsy.
      • Unlike Bell's palsy: no taste loss or retroauricular pain.
    • Visual disturbances:
      • Diplopia (resolves if one eye covered).
      • Causes: internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO), VI nerve palsy (rarely III/IV).
      • Bilateral INO highly suggestive of MS.
    • Cerebellar signs
  • Diagnosis:
    • No single diagnostic test.
    • Criteria for clinically definite MS:
      • ≥2 episodes of symptoms
      • ≥2 signs involving anatomically separate white matter tracts
      • Symptoms last >24 hrs, separated by ≥1 month.
    • If only 1 sign: confirm with MRI or evoked potentials.
  • Diagnostic Tests:

1. MRI

  • Typical lesions:
    • Periventricular (Dawson's fingers)
    • Corpus callosum, brainstem, cerebellum, spinal cord
    • 6 mm size helpful diagnostically

2. CSF Examination

  • Findings:
    • Mild mononuclear pleocytosis (~25% cases, esp. in young).
    • Intrathecal IgG synthesis (↑ IgG index, synthesis rate).
    • Oligoclonal bands (OCBs):
    • Present in >90% of MS cases.

3. Evoked Potentials:

  • Abnormalities in ≥1 EP modality found in 80-90% of MS patients.
  • Not specific to MS, but marked latency delay is highly suggestive.

Explanation of other options:

Stroke (Option B): Typically shows acute infarct or hemorrhage confined to a vascular territory, not multiple periventricular plaques disseminated in space and time.

Brain tumor (Option C): Appears as a space-occupying lesion with mass effect and edema, not multiple small white matter plaques.

Cerebral abscess (Option D): Shows ring-enhancing lesion with central necrosis and surrounding edema, not demyelinating plaques.

Key Takeaway:

  • Multiple sclerosis is diagnosed by MRI findings of periventricular demyelinating plaques (classically "Dawson's fingers"), with dissemination in time and space, distinguishing it from stroke, tumor, or abscess.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with a rapidly growing breast lump. The image below shows a clinical photograph of the breast. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Phyllodes tumor is a rapidly growing, large, bosselated breast mass that remains mobile on the chest wall and may cause skin ulceration due to pressure necrosis.

Phyllodes Tumour

  • Epidemiology:
    • Usually occurs in women >30 years, but can appear in younger women.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Presents as a large, sometimes massive tumour.
    • Surface: uneven, bosselated.
    • Overlying skin: may show ulceration due to pressure necrosis.
    • Remains mobile on the chest wall, rarely infiltrates skin until late.
  • Pathology:
    • True mixed neoplasm (epithelial + mesenchymal).
    • Resembles fibroadenoma.
    • May have higher mitotic index with infiltrating borders.
    • Rarely metastasises via bloodstream.
  • Histological Classification:
    • Benign: <4 mitoses / 10 HPF.
    • Borderline: 4-9 mitoses / 10 HPF.
    • Malignant: >10 mitoses / 10 HPF.
  • Treatment:
    • Wide Local Excision (WLE): with 2-cm margin, overlying skin & underlying pectoralis major.
    • Mastectomy: for massive, recurrent, or malignant tumours.
    • Adjuvant Radiotherapy: for recurrent or malignant tumours.
    • Chemotherapy: systemic, for malignant phyllodes.

Explanation of other options:

Fibroadenoma (Option B): Typically smaller, slow-growing, and seen in younger women; does not reach massive size or ulcerate skin.

Breast carcinoma (Option C): Often presents with hard, irregular, infiltrative mass with skin/nipple retraction, not a large mobile bosselated mass.

Breast cyst (Option D): Fluctuant, well-circumscribed, smooth, and not rapidly enlarging or bosselated.

Key Takeaway:

  • A rapidly enlarging, bosselated, mobile breast mass in women >30 years is highly suggestive of phyllodes tumor, requiring wide local excision with margins.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male presents with recurrent infections, eczema, and easy bruising. The image below shows a clinical photograph of the skin. Which gene mutation is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Mutations in the WASP gene cause Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome by impairing actin cytoskeleton assembly, leading to thrombocytopenia, eczema, and immunodeficiency.

Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome (WAS)

  • X-linked recessive disorder.
  • Classic triad: eczema (atopic dermatitis) + thrombocytopenia (small platelets) + recurrent infections.
  • Genetics & Pathogenesis:
    • Caused by mutations in WASP gene → defective actin cytoskeleton assembly (cell migration, cell-cell interaction).
  • Clinical Features:
    • Infancy: bleeding (circumcision site, bloody diarrhea).
    • Eczema (atopic dermatitis).
    • Recurrent infections: bacterial (Strep. pneumoniae, encapsulated organisms → otitis, pneumonia, meningitis, sepsis); later viral (EBV, herpesviruses) and fungal (P. jiroveci).
  • Diagnosis:
    • Immunoglobulin pattern: ↓IgM, ↑IgA, ↑IgE, normal/slightly ↓IgG.
    • Lymphocytes: reduced T cells, poor mitogen response.
    • Platelets: low number, small size (typical).
    • Poor antibody response: especially to polysaccharide antigens.
    • Antibody response to protein/conjugate vaccines may also be ↓.
  • Treatment:
    • Supportive care: nutrition, eczema care, antibiotics, killed vaccines
    • Immunoglobulin replacement: essential, regardless of serum Ig levels.
    • Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT): curative if good donor available.
    • Gene therapy: promising, though early trials had risk of malignancy.

Explanation of other options:

FLG gene (Option B): Causes ichthyosis vulgaris or atopic dermatitis, not combined immunodeficiency.

GP1BA gene (Option C): Associated with Bernard-Soulier syndrome (macrothrombocytopenia), not immunodeficiency or eczema.

DOCK8 gene (Option D): Causes autosomal recessive hyper-IgE syndrome with recurrent infections and eczema, but inheritance and lab findings differ.

Key Takeaway:

  • WAS is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by WASP gene mutations, presenting with the classic triad of eczema, thrombocytopenia (small platelets), and recurrent infections.

questions.text: A 12-year-old obese male presents with hip pain and a limp. The image below shows an X-ray of the hip. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The X-ray and clinical features indicate a posterior and superior displacement of the proximal femoral metaphysis relative to the epiphysis, characteristic of slipped capital femoral epiphysis.

Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis (SCFE)

  • Most common hip disorder in adolescents (age 10-15).
  • Incidence: ~1 per 10,000 worldwide.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Mechanical overload → displacement through proximal femoral physis, metaphysis moves anteriorly & superiorly relative to epiphysis.
    • Slipping occurs through the hypertrophic zone of the physis.
  • Biomechanical risk factors:
    • Increased femoral retroversion → torsional stress.
    • Varus neck-shaft angle → vertical physis → increased shear.
    • Obesity → more shear stress.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Pain: thigh, groin, or knee (isolated knee pain possible → delayed diagnosis).
    • Often post-trauma but may have prodromal symptoms.
    • Typical age: 12 years; <10 or >16 → suspect endocrine cause.
  • Physical Examination:
    • Leg: shortened, externally rotated.
    • Pain with hip ROM, especially log-roll.
    • Limitation: abduction, flexion, internal rotation.
    • Drehmann's sign: hip flexion → obligate external rotation & abduction.
    • Gait: antalgic or Trendelenburg, foot externally rotated.
  • Imaging:
    • Plain radiographs: AP + frog-leg lateral of both hips.
      • Early signs: widened/irregular physis, loss of head-neck concavity, metaphyseal border sharpening, reduced epiphyseal height.
    • Klein's line: line along superior femoral neck; failure to intersect epiphysis → positive Trethowan sign.
    • Steel sign: double-density/metaphyseal blanch on AP (posterior epiphysis overlap).
    • Capener's sign: reduction of double-density crescent (worsening lateral displacement).
    • Southwick angle: frog-lateral view; line perpendicular to physis vs femoral shaft. Normal ~12°; increases with severity.

Explanation of other options:

Perthes disease (Option B): Typically affects younger children (4-10 years), involves avascular necrosis of the femoral head, not physis slippage.

Developmental dysplasia of the hip (Option C): Presents earlier in infancy or toddler age, with hip instability or subluxation, not acute metaphyseal-epiphyseal displacement.

Femoral neck fracture (Option D): Usually post-traumatic, rare in children without significant trauma, and shows cortical disruption rather than physeal slippage.
